title: Box/Line Reduction
description: When a candidate in a row or column is confined to a single box, it can be eliminated from other cells in that box.

steps.title: What is Box/Line Reduction?
steps.content: Box/Line Reduction is the reverse of Pointing Pairs. When all candidates for a digit in a row (or column) fall within a single box, that digit can be eliminated from other cells in that box (outside the row/column).

steps.title: The reverse of Pointing Pairs
steps.content: With Pointing Pairs, you look inside a box and eliminate along a line. With Box/Line Reduction, you look along a line and eliminate inside a box. They're complementary techniques.

steps.title: Scan a row
steps.content: Look at this row. The digit 2 only appears as a candidate in cells that all fall within one 3×3 box. Nowhere else in the row can 2 go.

steps.title: Identify the box
steps.content: The candidates for 2 in this row are restricted to these cells, all within the same box. Since 2 must be in this row and these cells, 2 must be in this box in this row.

steps.title: Eliminate within the box
steps.content: Now we can remove 2 from all other cells in that box that aren't in our row. The digit 2 is claimed by the row's intersection with the box.

steps.title: Column version
steps.content: The same logic works for columns. If a digit in a column only appears within one box, eliminate that digit from other cells in the box that aren't in the column.

steps.title: Searching strategy
steps.content: For each row (or column), check each digit. If all candidates for that digit fall within a single box, check the rest of that box for eliminations. This technique pairs well with Pointing Pairs — always check both directions.

steps.title: Why it matters
steps.content: Box/Line Reduction and Pointing Pairs together form a powerful toolkit for intermediate puzzles. They exploit the interaction between rows/columns and boxes, opening up cells that basic techniques miss.
